We discuss some differences in the properties of both even and odd Fedosov
and Riemannian supermanifolds.

A Fedosov supermanifold (M, ω, Γ) is defined as a symplectic supermanifold (M, ω)
equipped with a symmetric connection Γ (or covariant derivative ∇) compatible with
a given symplectic structure ω: ω∇ = 0.1 In local coordinates {xi }, ǫ(xi ) = ǫi , on
the supermanifold M the symplectic structure is ω = ωij dxj ∧ dxi , ωij = −(−1)ǫi ǫj ωji
(Grassmann parity of the symplectic structure, ǫ(ω), is equal to 0 for even structure and 1
for odd structure) and the compatibility condition is ωij ∇k = ωij,k −Γijk +Γjik (−1)ǫi ǫj = 0
where Γijk = ωin Γnjk , ǫ(Γijk ) = ǫ(ω) + ǫi + ǫj + ǫk and Γijk are components of the
connection Γ. Notice that for a given symplectic structure ω there exists a large family of
connections satisfying the compatibility condition.
The curvature tensor field Rimjk is defined in terms of the commutator of covariant derivatives, [∇i , ∇j ] = ∇i ∇j − (−1)ǫi ǫj ∇j ∇i , whose action on a vector field T i is
T i [∇j , ∇k ] = −(−1)ǫm (ǫi +1) T m Rimjk .
It is convenient to describe the basic properties of Fedosov supermanifolds in terms
of the symplectic curvature tensor Rijkl = ωin Rnjkl , ǫ(Rijkl ) = ǫ(ω) + ǫi + ǫj + ǫk + ǫl ,.
This tensor obeys the symmetry properties
Rijkl = −(−1)ǫk ǫl Rijlk ,

(4)

We see that there are no formal differences in the properties of even and odd Fedosov
supermanifolds on the level of symplectic curvature tensor. With the curvature tensor,
Rijkl , and the inverse tensor field ω ij (ω ij = −(−1)ǫ(ω)+ǫi ǫj ω ji ) of the symplectic structure
ωij , one can construct the only tensor field of type (0, 2),
Kij = ω kn Rnikj (−1)ǫi ǫk +(ǫ(ω)+1)(ǫk +ǫn ) = Rkikj (−1)ǫk (ǫi +1) ,

ǫ(Kij ) = ǫi + ǫj .

(5)

This tensor satisfies the relations [1]
[1 + (−1)ǫ(ω) ](Kij − (−1)ǫi ǫj Kji ) = 0 ,

(6)

and is called the Ricci tensor. In the even case this tensor is symmetric whereas in the
odd case there are not restrictions on its (generalized) symmetry properties. The scalar
curvature tensor K is defined by the formula K = ω ji Kij (−1)ǫi +ǫj . From the symmetry
properties of Rijkl , it follows that
[1 + (−1)ǫ(ω) ]K = 0.

(7)

Therefore as in the case of Fedosov manifolds [4], even Fedosov supermanifolds have vanishing scalar curvature K. However, for odd Fedosov supermanifolds this curvature is, in
general, not vanishing. This fact was quite recently used in Ref. [5] to generalize the BV
formalism [6].
A Riemannian supermanifold (M, g, Γ) is defined as a metric supermanifold (M, g)
equipped with a symmetric connection Γ (or covariant derivative ∇) compatible with a
given metric structure g: g∇ = 0. In local coordinates on the supermanifold M the metric
structure is g = gij dxj dxi , gij = (−1)ǫi ǫj gji (Grassmann parity of the metric structure,
ǫ(g), is equal to 0 for even structure and 1 for odd structure) and the compatibility
condition is gij ∇k = gij,k − Γijk − Γjik (−1)ǫi ǫj = 0 where Γijk = gin Γnjk , ǫ(Γijk ) =
ǫ(g) + ǫi + ǫj + ǫk and Γijk are components of the connection Γ. Notice that for a given
metric structure g there exists the unique symmetric connection Γijk which is compatible
with a given metric structure,

the level of the curvature tensor there are no differences in the basic properties of even
and odd Riemannian supermanifolds.

Rij = Rk ikj (−1)ǫk (ǫi +1) = gkn Rnikj (−1)(ǫk +ǫn )(ǫ(g)+1)+ǫi ǫk ,

It is the generalized Ricci tensor with the following symmetry properties
Rij = (−1)ǫ(g)+ǫi ǫj Rji

(11)

depending on Riemannian supermanifolds to be even or odd. A further contraction defines
the scalar curvature
R = g ji Rij (−1)ǫi +ǫj ,

ǫ(R) = ǫ(g)

(12)

which, in general, is not equal to zero. Notice that for an odd metric structure the scalar
curvature tensor squared is identically equal to zero, R2 = 0.
From the Bianchi identity one can deduce the following relation between the scalar
curvature and the Ricci tensor
R,i = [1 + (−1)ǫ(g) ]Rj i;j (−1)ǫj (ǫi +1) ,

(13)

which in the even case is nothing but R,i = 2Rj i;j (−1)ǫj (ǫi +1) , i.e. the supersymmetric
generalization of known relation in Riemannian geometry [7]. In the odd case R,i = 0.
Therefore odd Riemann supermanifolds have constant scalar curvature, R = const.
